intro: Cerinthodes ellipticum, commonly known as the elliptic cerinthodes, is a flowering plant native to specific regions of South America. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its slender, branching stems and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments, such as forest undergrowth, and thrives in temperate climates. Its leaves are lance-shaped and have a mild, aromatic scent, while its flowers are usually white or pale yellow. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
